Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Situation2: They organize immediate support and counseling for community members facing a crisis, such as a natural disaster or sudden loss.
Story: The headset pressed against my ear as I watched the seconds tick by on my telemarketing dashboard. Every call, every break, every moment was tracked. The compliance system was merciless—one unscheduled minute, and I’d be flagged. My supervisor’s warnings echoed in my mind: “Stick to your schedule, or there will be consequences.” But then my phone buzzed with a message from the church secretary. A family in our congregation had just lost their home in a fire. They needed me—now. As their pastor, I was expected to be present, to offer comfort and guidance in their darkest hour. My heart ached, torn between the rigid demands of my job and the urgent needs of my community. I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. The clock kept ticking, and I felt myself caught in a tightening vise, unsure which duty to answer first.
